instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN_L: What is PCH_INTVRMEN_L? PCH_INTVRMEN_L is a signal that stands for Internal Voltage Regulator Enable. When pulled high, this signal enables the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must be pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4L: What is PM_SLP_S4L? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4L, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hi.

I have this <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> missing and also  <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> missing. I have  <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>(3.3v)  and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5v present. I tried reflow on SMC, I replaced <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> with no changes... No short lines all diode modes are good. I found that when plugged in only <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> warms up to 30 degrees and stays like that. I have a green light changes to orange and stays like that, also tried with multiple original known good adapters.

Any ideas pls? Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
If not, be sure both <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS are present.
Also check <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> and the 4 PCH's RTC signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>   Triggering, I checked it right away.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> Diode 0.3 and 3.3v, 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> diode 0.4 and 3.3v 
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> diode 0.5 and 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> diode 0.78 and 2.78, while measuring on pin 2 on <RESISTOR>R1450</RESISTOR> I got a brief fan spin and it turned off  :unsure: 
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - diode 0.7 and 3.4v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>  diode 0.5 and 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>  3.3v
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>  3.3v
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>  3.3v
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN_L</SIGNAL>  2.7v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>  3.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Also... There was corrosion on <CHIP>U3210</CHIP>, but no short. The ship was fine, but I replaced it together with <CAPACITOR>C3286</CAPACITOR>/<CAPACITOR>C3285</CAPACITOR> and rewire on pin 18 to the caps. Sorry I didn't start with this, maybe i should've mentioned it

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I asked you to check a specific reaction when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> (at same time)...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: When  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>  is triggered  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>  goes to 0.3v and comes back when the trigger is released.  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>  sometimes stays at 1v when plugger in and I need to trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>   to get 3.4v and then the same thing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> must stay all time high (3V), unless <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is triggered.
If not, you may have a problem with SMC, <RESISTOR>R1405</RESISTOR>, or <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> level.
When drops from 3V to 0V, (at same time) check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4L</SIGNAL> and L7520.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> gets 3.3v when <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>  is triggered and L7520 goes up to 5v and down to 0v.  <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>  diode mode is all good and E1405 it's 1k the way it should be

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Check for pulse at all big coils.
Also check pins 1, 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

Just in case, test if turns on in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> diode measurement is all good and I have only 3.3v on pin 8 nothing else.  SMC bypass mode starts and stops and doesn't continue with the fan at full speed. The coils when power pressed the voltages go up and come back to the initial state

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
So no pulse at all at <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>?
First remove <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> and test again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Actually, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> goes up when I plug in power and goes back down :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: With or without <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> now sometimes it will power on and stay on with the fan spinning all the time. When it's gonna power on I can switch it off from the power button switch on the board and power it on again. I haven't had the chance to see if it shows a picture when it powers on. I also replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> same thing...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
I said to remove <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> because you've said no pulse at all at <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> in previous post.
Please, post accurate information.
When it pulses, check if pin 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pulses too.
Also check <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> diode mode 0.5 and it pulses to 3.3v 2 times after I plug in power, but then it goes to 0v and stays like that. <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin 3 <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> it;s stable

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
2 pulses is the worst scenario for this board.
And we have several threads about it.
There is not a known solution; same symptom can be caused by various problems on the board.
Any history available?

You may have a problem with SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
I fixed few boards with accumulated crap underneath PCH.
Also check all voltages from page 11.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I will try to go through all resistors which might transfer a voltage and check them one by one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: The board came with no power and some corrosion on <CHIP>U3210</CHIP>, but no short. The chip was fine, but I replaced it together with <CAPACITOR>C3286</CAPACITOR>/<CAPACITOR>C3285</CAPACITOR> and rewire pin 18 to the caps as mentioned before

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: I did reflow on the CPU,still the same...
